p: Improvements in nutrient absorption and digestibility can result in improved growth rates within broilers ( Gous, 2010). Feed conversion ratio (FCR), the ratio between feed intake and average weight gain, is one of the more commonly used metrics to determine if a feed additive is beneficial to commercial livestock production ( Leenstra, 1986). Several studies have reported no improvement in growth rate or FCR when diets have been supplemented with EOs ( Lee et al., 2003; Jang et al., 2004, 2007). However, FCR and body weight gain (BWG) improvements have been observed in other studies that utilized EOs ( Denli et al., 2004; Cabuk et al., 2006; Basmacioğlu Malayoğlu et al., 2010). Cabuk et al. (2006) demonstrated that 24 or 48 mg/kg of Heryumix TM significantly improved FCR on days 21 to 1.53 and 1.56 compared to the control at 1.62. On day 42, compared to the control at 1.87, the FCR was also improved to 1.80 and 1.77 with 24 or 48 mg/kg of Heryumix TM ( Cabuk et al., 2006). Heryumix TM is composed of oregano, laurel leaf, sage, myrtle, fennel, and citrus peel extracts (Herba Gida Maddeleri; Seferihisar, Turkey). Denli et al. (2004) observed similar improvements in quail when their diet was supplemented with 60 mg/kg of thyme or black seed oil.
